soln_description:
## Subject 1.

a. Show that the number $a=2^{2 n+2} \cdot 7^{n+3}+11 \cdot 2^{2 n+5} \cdot 7^{n}+2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n+3}-27 \cdot 2^{2 n+1} \cdot 7^{n}$ is divisible by 2013, for any $n \in \mathbf{N}$.

b. Find the greatest common divisor of the numbers $a=3^{\mathrm{n}+1} \cdot 7^{\mathrm{n}}+4$ and $b=3^{\mathrm{n}} \cdot 7^{\mathrm{n}+1}+6$, where $\mathrm{n}$ is a natural number.

( G.M. 11- 2012)
informal_statement:
## Subject 1.

$$
\text { a. } \begin{aligned}
\mathrm{a} & =2^{2 n+2} \cdot 7^{n+3}+11 \cdot 2^{2 n+5} \cdot 7^{n}+2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n+3}-27 \cdot 2^{2 n+1} \cdot 7^{n} \\
& =2^{2 n} \cdot 2^{2} \cdot 7^{n} \cdot 7^{3}+11 \cdot 2^{2 n} \cdot 2^{5} \cdot 7^{n}+2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n} \cdot 7^{3}-27 \cdot 2^{2 n} \cdot 2^{1} \cdot 7^{n} \\
& =2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n} \cdot\left(2^{3} \cdot 7^{3}+11 \cdot 2^{5}+7^{3}-27 \cdot 2^{1}\right) \\
& =2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n} \cdot(4 \cdot 343+11 \cdot 32+343-54) \\
& =2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n} \cdot 2013
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, a is divisible by 2013

$3 \text{ points}$.
b.

Let d be a common divisor of the numbers a and b

$\mathrm{d} / 21^{\mathrm{n}} \cdot 3+4 \Rightarrow \mathrm{d} / 21^{\mathrm{n}+1}+28$

$\mathrm{d} / 21^{\mathrm{n}} \cdot 7+6 \Rightarrow \mathrm{d} / 21^{\mathrm{n}+1}+18 \Rightarrow \mathrm{d} / 10 \Rightarrow \mathrm{d} \in\{1,2,5,10\}$ $2 \text{ points}$

$u(a)=7, u(b)=3 \Rightarrow d=1$ $2 \text{ points}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Subject 1.

$$
\text { a. } \begin{aligned}
\mathrm{a} & =2^{2 n+2} \cdot 7^{n+3}+11 \cdot 2^{2 n+5} \cdot 7^{n}+2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n+3}-27 \cdot 2^{2 n+1} \cdot 7^{n} \\
& =2^{2 n} \cdot 2^{2} \cdot 7^{n} \cdot 7^{3}+11 \cdot 2^{2 n} \cdot 2^{5} \cdot 7^{n}+2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n} \cdot 7^{3}-27 \cdot 2^{2 n} \cdot 2^{1} \cdot 7^{n} \\
& =2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n} \cdot\left(2^{3} \cdot 7^{3}+11 \cdot 2^{5}+7^{3}-27 \cdot 2^{1}\right) \\
& =2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n} \cdot(4 \cdot 343+11 \cdot 32+343-54) \\
& =2^{2 n} \cdot 7^{n} \cdot 2013
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, a is divisible by 2013

$3 \text{ points}$.
b.

Let d be a common divisor of the numbers a and b

$\mathrm{d} / 21^{\mathrm{n}} \cdot 3+4 \Rightarrow \mathrm{d} / 21^{\mathrm{n}+1}+28$

$\mathrm{d} / 21^{\mathrm{n}} \cdot 7+6 \Rightarrow \mathrm{d} / 21^{\mathrm{n}+1}+18 \Rightarrow \mathrm{d} / 10 \Rightarrow \mathrm{d} \in\{1,2,5,10\}$ $2 \text{ points}$

$u(a)=7, u(b)=3 \Rightarrow d=1$ $2 \text{ points}$ -/
theorem number_theory_98719 {a b : ℤ} (ha : a = 2^(2*n + 2) * 7^(n + 3) + 11 * 2^(2*n + 5) * 7^n + 2^(2*n) * 7^(n + 3) - 27 * 2^(2*n + 1) * 7^n)
    (hb : b = 2^(2*n + 1) * 7^(n + 2) + 11 * 2^(2*n + 4) * 7^n + 2^(2*n) * 7^(n + 2) - 27 * 2^(2*n + 1) * 7^n) :
    2013 ∣ a ∧ 2013 ∣ b ∧ IsGreatest {d | d ∣ a ∧ d ∣ b} 1 := by

soln_description:
(1) Take 100 sets: $\left\{a_{i}, 201-a_{i}\right\}, i=1,2, \cdots, 100$. According to the problem, $G$ contains at most one number from each set, and $G$ has 100 numbers in total, so exactly one number is selected from each set. Divide these 100 sets into two categories: (1) $\{4 k+1,200-4 k\}(k=0,1, \cdots, 49)$; (2) $\{4 j-1,202-$ $4 j\}(j=1,2, \cdots, 50)$, each category has 50 sets. Suppose $m$ odd numbers and $50-m$ even numbers are selected from the first category, and $n$ odd numbers and $50-n$ even numbers are selected from the second category.

Since $1 \cdot m+0 \cdot(50-m)+(-1) \cdot n+2 \cdot(50-n) \equiv 10080 \equiv 0(\bmod 4)$ $\Rightarrow m-3 n \equiv 0(\bmod 4) \Rightarrow m+n \equiv 0(\bmod 4)$, the number of odd numbers in $G$ is a multiple of 4.
(2) Let the 100 selected numbers be $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{100}$, and the 100 unselected numbers be $201-a_{1}, 201-a_{2}$, $\cdots, 201-a_{100}$. According to the problem, $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{100}=10080$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{100}^{2}+\left(201-a_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(201-a_{2}\right)^{2}+\cdots+\left(201-a_{100}\right)^{2} \\
=2\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{100}^{2}\right)-402\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{100}\right)+100 \cdot 201^{2} \\
=2\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{100}^{2}\right)-402 \cdot 10080+100 \cdot 201^{2}=1^{2}+2^{2}+\cdots+200^{2} \\
\Rightarrow a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{100}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(1^{2}+2^{2}+\cdots+200^{2}+402 \cdot 10080-100 \cdot 201^{2}\right) \\
=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{6} \cdot 200 \cdot 201 \cdot 401+201 \cdot 60\right)=1349380 .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
2. Let $E=\{1,2, \cdots, 200\}, G=\left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \cdots, a_{100}\right\} \varsubsetneqq E$ and $G$ has the following two properties:
(1) For any $1 \leqslant i \leqslant j \leqslant 100$, it always holds that $a_{i}+a_{j} \neq 201$;
(2) $\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}=10080$.
Prove: The number of odd numbers in $G$ is a multiple of 4, and the sum of the squares of all numbers in $G$ is a constant.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Let $E=\{1,2, \cdots, 200\}, G=\left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \cdots, a_{100}\right\} \varsubsetneqq E$ and $G$ has the following two properties:
(1) For any $1 \leqslant i \leqslant j \leqslant 100$, it always holds that $a_{i}+a_{j} \neq 201$;
(2) $\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}=10080$.
Prove: The number of odd numbers in $G$ is a multiple of 4, and the sum of the squares of all numbers in $G$ is a constant. -/
theorem number_theory_259695 (E : Finset ℕ) (G : Finset ℕ)
    (hG : G ⊂ E) (hG1 : ∀ i ∈ G, ∀ j ∈ G, i ≤ j → i + j ≠ 201)
    (hG2 : ∑ i ∈ G, i = 10080) :
    4 ∣ {x | x ∈ G ∧ Odd x}.ncard ∧
    ∃ c, ∑ i ∈ G, i^2 = c := by

soln_description: If $a, b$ are both odd or one odd and one even, then $a^{2}+a b+b^{2}$ is odd, and cannot equal 2018; if $a, b$ are both even, then $a^{2}+a b+b^{2}$ is divisible by 4, while 2018 is not divisible by 4, therefore the solution set of the equation $a^{2}+a b+b^{2}=2018$ is $\varnothing$.
informal_statement: 8. The set of positive integer solutions $(a, b)$ that satisfy $a^{2}+a b+b^{2}=2018$ is
informal_proof:
We are asked to find the number of positive integer solutions $(a, b)$ to the equation $a^2 + ab + b^2 = 2018$.

Let's analyze the equation modulo 3.
First, we compute the remainder of 2018 when divided by 3:
$2018 = 3 \times 672 + 2$, so $2018 \equiv 2 \pmod 3$.
Thus, any integer solution $(a, b)$ must satisfy $a^2 + ab + b^2 \equiv 2 \pmod 3$.

Now, we consider the possible remainders of $a$ and $b$ when divided by 3. For any integer $x$, $x \pmod 3$ can be $0$, $1$, or $2$. We examine all $3 \times 3 = 9$ possible pairs of $(a \pmod 3, b \pmod 3)$:

1.  If $a \equiv 0 \pmod 3$ and $b \equiv 0 \pmod 3$, then $a^2 + ab + b^2 \equiv 0^2 + (0)(0) + 0^2 \equiv 0 \pmod 3$.
2.  If $a \equiv 0 \pmod 3$ and $b \equiv 1 \pmod 3$, then $a^2 + ab + b^2 \equiv 0^2 + (0)(1) + 1^2 \equiv 1 \pmod 3$.
3.  If $a \equiv 0 \pmod 3$ and $b \equiv 2 \pmod 3$, then $a^2 + ab + b^2 \equiv 0^2 + (0)(2) + 2^2 \equiv 4 \equiv 1 \pmod 3$.
4.  If $a \equiv 1 \pmod 3$ and $b \equiv 0 \pmod 3$, then $a^2 + ab + b^2 \equiv 1^2 + (1)(0) + 0^2 \equiv 1 \pmod 3$.
5.  If $a \equiv 1 \pmod 3$ and $b \equiv 1 \pmod 3$, then $a^2 + ab + b^2 \equiv 1^2 + (1)(1) + 1^2 \equiv 1 + 1 + 1 \equiv 3 \equiv 0 \pmod 3$.
6.  If $a \equiv 1 \pmod 3$ and $b \equiv 2 \pmod 3$, then $a^2 + ab + b^2 \equiv 1^2 + (1)(2) + 2^2 \equiv 1 + 2 + 4 \equiv 7 \equiv 1 \pmod 3$.
7.  If $a \equiv 2 \pmod 3$ and $b \equiv 0 \pmod 3$, then $a^2 + ab + b^2 \equiv 2^2 + (2)(0) + 0^2 \equiv 4 \equiv 1 \pmod 3$.
8.  If $a \equiv 2 \pmod 3$ and $b \equiv 1 \pmod 3$, then $a^2 + ab + b^2 \equiv 2^2 + (2)(1) + 1^2 \equiv 4 + 2 + 1 \equiv 7 \equiv 1 \pmod 3$.
9.  If $a \equiv 2 \pmod 3$ and $b \equiv 2 \pmod 3$, then $a^2 + ab + b^2 \equiv 2^2 + (2)(2) + 2^2 \equiv 4 + 4 + 4 \equiv 12 \equiv 0 \pmod 3$.

In all cases, $a^2 + ab + b^2 \pmod 3$ is either $0$ or $1$.
Since $2018 \equiv 2 \pmod 3$, the equation $a^2 + ab + b^2 = 2018$ cannot have any integer solutions. Therefore, it cannot have any positive integer solutions. The set of such solutions is empty.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8. The set of positive integer solutions $(a, b)$ that satisfy $a^{2}+a b+b^{2}=2018$ is -/
theorem number_theory_248390 (a b : ℤ) (ha : a > 0) (hb : b > 0)
    (h : a^2 + a * b + b^2 = 2018) :
    False := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_248390 (a b : ℤ) (ha : a > 0) (hb : b > 0)
    (h : a^2 + a * b + b^2 = 2018) :
    False := by 
  have h1 : (a^2 + a * b + b^2) % 3 = 2 := by 
    omega 
  have h4 : (a^2 + a * b + b^2) % 3 = 0 ∨ (a^2 + a * b + b^2) % 3 = 1 := by 
    have h2 : a % 3 = 0 ∨ a % 3 = 1 ∨ a % 3 = 2 := by 
      omega 
    have h3 : b % 3 = 0 ∨ b % 3 = 1 ∨ b % 3 = 2 := by 
      omega 
    rcases h2 with (h2 | h2 | h2) <;> rcases h3 with (h3 | h3 | h3) <;> 
      simp [pow_two, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod, h2, h3] at *
      <;> omega 
  omega

informal_statement:
Let $S$ denote the set of all 6-tuples $(a, b, c, d, e, f)$ of positive integers such that $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}+e^{2}=$ $f^{2}$. Consider the set

$$
T=\{a b c d e f:(a, b, c, d, e, f) \in S\}
$$

Find the greatest common divisor of all the members of $T$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $S$ denote the set of all 6-tuples $(a, b, c, d, e, f)$ of positive integers such that $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}+e^{2}=$ $f^{2}$. Consider the set

$$
T=\{a b c d e f:(a, b, c, d, e, f) \in S\}
$$

Find the greatest common divisor of all the members of $T$. -/
theorem number_theory_607813 :
    IsGreatest {x | ∀ a b c d e f : ℕ, a > 0 → b > 0 → c > 0 → d > 0 → e > 0 → f > 0 →
      a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2 + e^2 = f^2 → x ∣ a * b * c * d * e * f} 24 := by

soln_description:
Given that $f(x)-f(2-x)=0$ holds for any $x \in \mathbf{R}$, we have $f(1+x)=f[2-(1+x)]$, which means $f(1+x)=f(1-x)$. Therefore, the graph of the function $y=f(x)$ is symmetric about the line $x=1$.

Key Points for Solving the Problem: For the function $y=f(x)(x \in D)$, if $f(a+x)=f(a-x)$ holds for any $x$ in the domain, then the graph of this function is symmetric about the line $x=a$; if $\frac{1}{2}[f(a+x)+f(a-x)]=b$ holds for any $x$ in the domain, then the graph of this function is symmetric about the point $(a, b)$.
informal_statement: Example 5 Given that the function $y=f(x)$ defined on $\mathbf{R}$ satisfies $f(x)-f(2-$ $x)=0$ for any $x \in \mathbf{R}$, is its graph an axis-symmetric figure? If so, write down the equation of the axis of symmetry.
informal_proof:
Let the given condition be $f(x) - f(2 - x) = 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$.
This equality can be rewritten as $f(x) = f(2 - x)$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

We are asked to show that there exists a real number $a$ such that for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $f(x) = f(2a - x)$.
Let us choose $a = 1$. We then need to verify if the condition $f(x) = f(2 \cdot 1 - x)$ holds for all $x$.
The expression $2 \cdot 1 - x$ simplifies to $2 - x$ by basic arithmetic.
Thus, the condition we need to verify is $f(x) = f(2 - x)$.

As shown above, the given condition $f(x) - f(2 - x) = 0$ is equivalent to $f(x) = f(2 - x)$.
Therefore, with $a=1$, the property $f(x) = f(2a - x)$ holds for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$.
This establishes the existence of such an $a$, which is $1$, and confirms that the graph of $f$ is symmetric about the line $x=1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 5 Given that the function $y=f(x)$ defined on $\mathbf{R}$ satisfies $f(x)-f(2-$ $x)=0$ for any $x \in \mathbf{R}$, is its graph an axis-symmetric figure? If so, write down the equation of the axis of symmetry. -/
theorem algebra_227024 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (h : ∀ x, f x - f (2 - x) = 0) :
    ∃ a, ∀ x, f x = f (2 * a - x) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_227024 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (h : ∀ x, f x - f (2 - x) = 0) :
    ∃ a, ∀ x, f x = f (2 * a - x) := by
  use 1
  intro x
  have h1 : f x = f (2 - x) := by 
    have h_eq : f x - f (2 - x) = 0 := h x
    linarith 
  rw [show 2 * (1 : ℝ) - x = (2 - x) by ring]
  exact h1

soln_description:
Answer: $x=0, x=2$

Solution: The domain of this equation is the interval [0;2]. On this interval, both terms are non-negative. Their sum is zero only when both are zero. The first term is zero at $x=-1,0,2$, and the second term is zero at $x=0,2,3$. Only 0 and 2 coincide.

informal_statement: 8. Solve the equation $x^{7} \cdot \sqrt{2+x-x^{2}}+(2-x)^{11} \cdot \sqrt{3 x-x^{2}}=0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8. Solve the equation $x^{7} \cdot \sqrt{2+x-x^{2}}+(2-x)^{11} \cdot \sqrt{3 x-x^{2}}=0$. -/
theorem algebra_194343 (x : ℝ) :
    x^7 * Real.sqrt (2 + x - x^2) + (2 - x)^11 * Real.sqrt (3 * x - x^2) = 0 ↔ x = 0 ∨ x = 2 := by

soln_description:
Solution.

According to the condition, we have the system $\left\{\begin{array}{l}100 A+B=121 B, \\ 100 B+A=84 A+14,\end{array}\right.$ from which $A=42, B=35$.

Answer: 42 and 35.
informal_statement: 13.305. Find two two-digit numbers $A$ and $B$ under the following conditions. If the number $A$ is written before the number $B$, and the resulting four-digit number is divided by the number $B$, the quotient is 121. If the number $B$ is written before the number $A$, and the resulting four-digit number is divided by $A$, the quotient is 84 and the remainder is 14.
informal_proof:
We are looking for two two-digit natural numbers, $A$ and $B$. The problem provides two conditions involving these numbers.

The first condition states that if the number $A$ is written before the number $B$, the resulting four-digit number, formed by concatenating $A$ and $B$, is $100A + B$. When this four-digit number is divided by $B$, the quotient is 121. This can be expressed algebraically as:
$100A + B = 121 \times B$

The second condition states that if the number $B$ is written before the number $A$, the resulting four-digit number, formed by concatenating $B$ and $A$, is $100B + A$. When this four-digit number is divided by $A$, the quotient is 84 and the remainder is 14. This can be expressed using the definition of division with remainder as:
$100B + A = 84 \times A + 14$

Additionally, we are given that both $A$ and $B$ are two-digit numbers. This means that $A$ must be in the range of integers from 10 to 99, inclusive, and similarly, $B$ must be in the range of integers from 10 to 99, inclusive.

To find the values of $A$ and $B$, we can systematically check all possible pairs of two-digit numbers. For each pair $(A, B)$ where $A \in [10, 99]$ and $B \in [10, 99]$, we verify if the two conditions derived above are simultaneously satisfied.

Let's check the first condition: $100A + B = 121B$.
Subtracting $B$ from both sides gives $100A = 120B$.
Dividing both sides by 20 simplifies this to $5A = 6B$.

Now let's check the second condition: $100B + A = 84A + 14$.
Subtracting $A$ from both sides gives $100B = 83A + 14$.

We now need to find a pair of two-digit integers $(A, B)$ that satisfies both $5A = 6B$ and $100B = 83A + 14$.

By examining the first equation, $5A = 6B$, we can see that $A$ must be a multiple of 6 (since 5 and 6 are coprime), and $B$ must be a multiple of 5. Let $A = 6k$ and $B = 5k$ for some integer $k$.
Since $A$ and $B$ are two-digit numbers, $10 \leq A \leq 99$ and $10 \leq B \leq 99$.
This means $10 \leq 6k \leq 99$, which implies $10/6 \leq k \leq 99/6$, so $1.66\ldots \leq k \leq 16.5$.
And $10 \leq 5k \leq 99$, which implies $10/5 \leq k \leq 99/5$, so $2 \leq k \leq 19.8$.
Combining these, $k$ must be an integer such that $2 \leq k \leq 16$.

Now we substitute $A=6k$ and $B=5k$ into the second equation $100B = 83A + 14$:
$100(5k) = 83(6k) + 14$
$500k = 498k + 14$
$2k = 14$
$k = 7$

Since $k=7$ is within the valid range $2 \leq k \leq 16$, we have found our solution.
Substituting $k=7$ back into our expressions for $A$ and $B$:
$A = 6k = 6 \times 7 = 42$
$B = 5k = 5 \times 7 = 35$

Both $A=42$ and $B=35$ are indeed two-digit numbers. Let's verify these values with the original conditions:

Condition 1: $\frac{100 \times 42 + 35}{35} = \frac{4200 + 35}{35} = \frac{4235}{35}$.
Dividing 4235 by 35: $4235 = 35 \times 121$. So, the quotient is 121. This condition is satisfied.

Condition 2: $\frac{100 \times 35 + 42}{42} = \frac{3500 + 42}{42} = \frac{3542}{42}$.
Dividing 3542 by 42: $3542 = 42 \times 84 + 14$. So, the quotient is 84 and the remainder is 14. This condition is also satisfied.

Therefore, the two two-digit numbers are $A=42$ and $B=35$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 13.305. Find two two-digit numbers $A$ and $B$ under the following conditions. If the number $A$ is written before the number $B$, and the resulting four-digit number is divided by the number $B$, the quotient is 121. If the number $B$ is written before the number $A$, and the resulting four-digit number is divided by $A$, the quotient is 84 and the remainder is 14. -/
theorem algebra_176830 {A B : ℕ} (hA : A ∈ Finset.Icc 10 99) (hB : B ∈ Finset.Icc 10 99)
    (h1 : (100 * A + B) / B = 121) (h2 : (100 * B + A) / A = 84 ∧ (100 * B + A) % A = 14) :
    A = 42 ∧ B = 35 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_176830 {A B : ℕ} (hA : A ∈ Finset.Icc 10 99) (hB : B ∈ Finset.Icc 10 99)
    (h1 : (100 * A + B) / B = 121) (h2 : (100 * B + A) / A = 84 ∧ (100 * B + A) % A = 14) :
    A = 42 ∧ B = 35 := by
  rw [Finset.mem_Icc] at hA hB
  rcases h2 with ⟨h21, h22⟩
  rcases hA with ⟨hA1, hA2⟩
  rcases hB with ⟨hB1, hB2⟩
  interval_cases A <;> interval_cases B <;> norm_num at h1 h21 h22 
    <;> tauto

informal_statement: What fraction of $\frac{1}{2}$ is represented by $\frac{1}{7}$? Specifically, calculate $\frac{\frac{1}{7}}{\frac{1}{2}}$.
informal_proof:
We are asked to compute the value of the expression $\frac{\frac{1}{7}}{\frac{1}{2}}$.

This is a division of one rational number by another. To perform this division, we can multiply the numerator by the reciprocal of the denominator. The reciprocal of $\frac{1}{2}$ is $\frac{2}{1}$, which simplifies to $2$.

Therefore, the expression can be rewritten as:
$$ \frac{1}{7} \times 2 $$
Multiplying a fraction by an integer involves multiplying the numerator by the integer while keeping the denominator the same:
$$ \frac{1 \times 2}{7} = \frac{2}{7} $$
Thus, the value of the given expression is $\frac{2}{7}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- What fraction of $\frac{1}{2}$ is represented by $\frac{1}{7}$? Specifically, calculate $\frac{\frac{1}{7}}{\frac{1}{2}}$. -/
theorem algebra_72 : (1 / 7 : ℚ) / (1 / 2) = 2 / 7 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_72 : (1 / 7 : ℚ) / (1 / 2) = 2 / 7 := by
  norm_num

informal_statement: Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? -/
theorem algebra_14378 (a b : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h : a * 30 = b * 6 + 1 / 3) :
    b = 4 := by

soln_description:
10. (1) When $n \geqslant 2$, by the AM-GM inequality we have
$$
a_{n}=\frac{a_{n-1}^{2}+3}{2 a_{n-1}} \geqslant \sqrt{3} \text {. }
$$

Since $a_{n}$ is a rational number, we have $a_{n}>\sqrt{3}$.
Thus, $a_{n+1}-a_{n}=\frac{3-a_{n}^{2}}{2 a_{n}}<0$, which means the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is strictly decreasing.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { (2) From } a_{n+1}=\frac{a_{n}^{2}+3}{2 a_{n}} \\
\Rightarrow \frac{a_{n+1}-\sqrt{3}}{a_{n+1}+\sqrt{3}}=\left(\frac{a_{n}-\sqrt{3}}{a_{n}+\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2} \\
\Rightarrow \frac{a_{n+1}-\sqrt{3}}{a_{n+1}+\sqrt{3}}=r^{2^{n}}\left(r=\left|\frac{a_{1}-\sqrt{3}}{a_{1}+\sqrt{3}}\right|=2-\sqrt{3}\right) \\
\text { Hence } a_{n+1}=\frac{\sqrt{3}\left(1+r^{2^{n}}\right)}{1-r^{2^{n}}} \\
\Rightarrow\left|a_{n+1}-\sqrt{3}\right|=\frac{2 \sqrt{3} r^{2^{n}}}{1-r^{2^{2}}} .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
10. (21 points) Let the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfy
$$
a_{1}=1, a_{n+1}=\frac{a_{n}^{2}+3}{2 a_{n}}(n \geqslant 1) .
$$

Prove: (1) When $n \geqslant 2$, the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is strictly monotonically decreasing;
(2) When $n \geqslant 1$,
$$
\left|a_{n+1}-\sqrt{3}\right|=\frac{2 \sqrt{3} r^{2^{n}}}{1-r^{2^{n^{2}}}}(r=2-\sqrt{3}) .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 10. (21 points) Let the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfy
$$
a_{1}=1, a_{n+1}=\frac{a_{n}^{2}+3}{2 a_{n}}(n \geqslant 1) .
$$

Prove: (1) When $n \geqslant 2$, the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is strictly monotonically decreasing;
(2) When $n \geqslant 1$,
$$
\left|a_{n+1}-\sqrt{3}\right|=\frac{2 \sqrt{3} r^{2^{n}}}{1-r^{2^{n^{2}}}}(r=2-\sqrt{3}) .
$$ -/
theorem algebra_300251 {a : ℕ → ℝ} (ha1 : a 1 = 1)
    (han : ∀ n ≥ 1, a (n + 1) = (a n ^ 2 + 3) / (2 * a n)) :
    (∀ n ≥ 2, StrictAntiOn a {x | x ≥ n}) ∧
    (∀ n ≥ 1, |a (n + 1) - sqrt 3| = 2 * sqrt 3 * (2 - sqrt 3) ^ (2 ^ n) / (1 - (2 - sqrt 3) ^ (2 ^ (n ^ 2)))) := by

soln_description:
[Proof] In any sequence of ten consecutive integers,
there are exactly 5 numbers divisible by 2;
at most 4 numbers are divisible by 3, but among them, at most 2 are not even;
at most 2 numbers are divisible by 7, but among them, at most one is not even;
exactly 2 numbers are divisible by 5, but only one of them is not even.
Therefore, in any sequence of ten consecutive integers, the number of integers that cannot be divided by 2, 3, 5, or 7 is at least \(10 - (5 + 2 + 1 + 1) = 1\). Let this number be \(a\).
We will prove that \(a\) is coprime with the other nine numbers.
Let \(b\) be any one of the other nine numbers.
If \(p\) is a common prime divisor of \(a\) and \(b\),
since \(|a - b| \leq 9\), \(p\) must be one of 2, 3, 5, or 7. However, \(a\) cannot be divided by 2, 3, 5, or 7, so \(p\) cannot be any of 2, 3, 5, or 7. Therefore, \(a\) and \(b\) cannot have a common prime divisor, so \(a\) and \(b\) are coprime.
Thus, \(a\) is coprime with the other nine numbers.
informal_statement:
6.12 Prove that in any sequence of ten consecutive integers, there is at least one number that is relatively prime to all the other nine.
(27th Annual William Lowell Putnam Mathematical Competition, 1966)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6.12 Prove that in any sequence of ten consecutive integers, there is at least one number that is relatively prime to all the other nine.
(27th Annual William Lowell Putnam Mathematical Competition, 1966) -/
theorem number_theory_274206 (n : ℤ) :
    ∃ m ∈ Finset.Icc n (n + 9), ∀ k ∈ Finset.Icc n (n + 9), m ≠ k → IsCoprime m k := by
